questions.question: 1. A random variable $X$ is uniformly distributed in the interval (0,3). Another random variable $Y = e^{-2X}. The PDF of Y is$

explanations.a: $\text{Given, } Y = e^{-2X}  \Rightarrow X = -\frac{1}{2} \ln(Y) = h(Y) \text{ (let) } \Rightarrow \frac{dX}{dY} = -\frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{1}{Y} \text{Now, } f_Y(y) = f_X(x) \cdot \left| \frac{dx}{dy} \right| \text{Also, } f_X(x) = \frac{1}{3}; 0 \leq X \leq 3 \text{ and } Y = e^{-2X} \text{When, } X = 0 \to Y = 1 \text{ and when } X = 3 \to Y = e^{-6} \text{Thus, } Y \text{ exists in } (e^{-6}, 1) \text{ interval, and } f_Y(y) = \frac{1}{3} \left| -\frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{1}{Y} \right| \Rightarrow f_Y(y) = \frac{1}{6Y}; e^{-6} \leq Y \leq 1$

questions.question: 2. A random variable $X$ is uniformly distributed over $[-1,4]$. A new random variable $Y$ is defined such that $Y = 2X+5$. Then the probability density function $f_Y(y)$ is given by:

explanations.a: $\text{When one random variable is a function of another random variable, then there are two things that need to be found.} \text{(a) The range in which the new random variable exists.} \\ \text{(b) The magnitude of the random variable in this range.} \text{The range can be found simply by using the function given. Here,} Y = 2X + 5 \text{So, when,} x = -1, y = 3 \quad \text{and when} \quad x = 4, y = 13 \text{Thus } y \text{ exists in the range } [3, 13]. \text{Next, to find the magnitude, we use the relation:} f_Y(y) = f_X(x) \cdot \left| \frac{df(x)}{dy} \right| \text{Where } f(x) \text{ is a function expressing X in terms of Y.} \text{Here,} Y = 2X + 5 \quad \Rightarrow \quad X = \frac{Y - 5}{2} \Rightarrow \left| \frac{df(x)}{dy} \right| = \frac{1}{2} \text{Thus,} f_Y(y) = f_X(x) \cdot \frac{1}{2} = \frac{1}{5} \cdot \frac{1}{2} = \frac{1}{10} \text{Thus,} f_Y(y) = \left\{ \begin{array}{ll} \frac{1}{10}, & 3 \le y \le 13 \\ 0, & otherwise \end{array} \right. \text{Notice that to use the above relation, the function relating X and Y should be monotonic.}$

questions.question: 3. Let $X$ and $Y$ be two statistically independent random variables uniformly distributed in the ranges $(-1, 1)$ and $(-2, 1)$ respectively. Let $Z = X + Y$. Then the probability that $Z \leq -2$ is

explanations.a: $\text{Given that the random variables are uniformly distributed between (-1, 1) and (-2, 1). So, we have their probability density functions:} f_X(x) = \frac{1}{{1 - (-1)}} = \frac{1}{2}, \text{ for } -1 < X < 1 f_Y(y) = \frac{1}{{1 - (-2)}} = \frac{1}{3}, \text{ for } -2 < Y < 1. \text{For a random variable } Z = X + Y, \text{ the probability distribution function is defined as:} F_Z(z) = P\{X + Y \leq z\} = \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \left[ \int_{-\infty}^{z - x} f_{X,Y}(x,y) \, dy \right] dx. \text{So, the probability for } X + Y \leq -2 \text{ or } Z \leq -2 \text{ is given by:} F_Z(-2) = P\{X + Y \leq -2\} = \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \int_{-\infty}^{-2 - x} f_{X,Y}(x,y) \, dy \, dx \quad \text{(1)}. \text{Since the random variables X and Y are independent, the joint probability density function is:} f_{X,Y}(x,y) = f_X(x)f_Y(y) = \frac{1}{2} \times \frac{1}{3} = \frac{1}{6}, \text{for } -1 < X < 1 \text{ and } -2 < Y < 1. \text{For the region } X + Y \leq -2, \text{ the maximum value of X is obtained for the minimum value of Y, i.e., } -1 < X < 0 \text{ (x } \leq 0 \text{ for y = -2)}. \text{Substituting the intervals and value of the joint probability density function in equation (1), we get:} P\{X + Y \leq -2\} = \int_{-1}^0 \int_{-2}^{-2 - x} \frac{1}{6} \, dy \, dx = \frac{1}{12} = 0.0833.$

questions.question: 4. Let $X$ and $Y$ be two independent random variables where $X$ is exponentially distributed of rate $\lambda_1$ and $Y$ is exponentially distributed of rate $\lambda_2$. Let $Z = \min(X, Y)$. Find the density of $Z$ given by $f_Z(a)$.

explanations.a: $ P(Z > a) = P(\min(X, Y) > a) = P(X > a, Y > a) = P(X > a)P(Y > a) = e^{-(\lambda_1 + \lambda_2)a}.$ So it follows that $f_Z(a) = \left\{ \begin{array}{ll} (\lambda_1 + \lambda_2)e^{-(\lambda_1 + \lambda_2)a} & \text{for } a \geq 0 \\ 0 & \text{otherwise} \end{array} \right.$
explanations.b: $ P(Z > a) = P(\min(X, Y) > a) = P(X > a, Y > a) = P(X > a)P(Y > a) = e^{-(\lambda_1 + \lambda_2)a}.$ So it follows that $f_Z(a) = \left\{ \begin{array}{ll} (\lambda_1 + \lambda_2)e^{-(\lambda_1 + \lambda_2)a} & \text{for } a \geq 0 \\ 0 & \text{otherwise} \end{array} \right.$
explanations.d: $ P(Z > a) = P(\min(X, Y) > a) = P(X > a, Y > a) = P(X > a)P(Y > a) = e^{-(\lambda_1 + \lambda_2)a}.$ So it follows that $f_Z(a) = \left\{ \begin{array}{ll} (\lambda_1 + \lambda_2)e^{-(\lambda_1 + \lambda_2)a} & \text{for } a \geq 0 \\ 0 & \text{otherwise} \end{array} \right.$
